revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=June 2015}} {{multiple image|perrow=1|total_width=300|caption_align=center | image1 = Korea-Seoul-Insadong-Sanchon-02.jpg|caption1=A vegetarian dinner at a Korean Buddhist restaurant. | image2 = japanese temple vegetarian dinner.jpg|caption2=A vegetarian dinner at a Japanese Buddhist restaurant. | image3 = Chinese-buddhist-cuisine-taiwan-1.jpg|caption3=A vegetarian dinner at a Taiwanese Buddhist restaurant. }} '''Buddhist vegetarianism''' is the belief that following a [[vegetarianism|vegetarian]] diet is implied in the [[Gautama Buddha|Buddha]]'s teaching. In [[Buddhism]], however, the views on vegetarianism vary between different [[Schools of Buddhism|schools]] of thought. According to [[Theravada]], the Buddha allowed his [[Buddhist monk|monks]] to eat [[pork]], [[chicken]] and [[fish]] if the monk was aware that the animal was not killed on their behalf. The [[Mahayana]] schools generally recommend a vegetarian diet; according to some [[Sutra|sutras]] the Buddha himself insisted that his followers should not eat the flesh of any sentient being.<ref>[http://www.shabkar.org/scripture/sutras/index.htm Sutras on refraining from eating meat]</ref> Monks of the Mahayana traditions that follow the [[Brahma Net Sutra]] are forbidden by their vows from eating flesh of any kind.
==Early Buddhism== The earliest surviving written accounts of Buddhism are the Edicts of Asoka written by King [[Asoka]], a well-known Buddhist king who propagated Buddhism throughout Asia and is honored by both Theravada and Mahayana schools of Buddhism. The authority of the Edicts of Asoka as a historical record is suggested by the mention of numerous topics omitted as well as corroboration of numerous accounts found in the Theravada and Mahayana Tripitakas written down centuries later. <ref>{{cite web |url=https://journals.ub.uni-heidelberg.de/index.php/jiabs/article/viewFile/8572/2479 |website=Heidelberger OJS-Journals (Universitäts-Bibliothek Heidelberg) |title=Journal of International Association of Buddhist Studies – Asoka and Buddhism - A Reexamination : Presidential Address Given on the Occasion of the Fourth Conference of the IABS Madison, Wisconsin, August, 1980 |last=Bashram |first=A.L. |quote=on pp 131-132 : “The Kalinga war, which according to the 13th Rock Edict, was the main factor in Asoka’s conversion to Buddhism is not mentioned in either the Theravada tradition or in the Asokavadana, which, since it was transmitted mainly in Mahayana circles, we shall refer to it as the Mahayana tradition…” and on page 141:”It is not wholly clear what form of Buddhism Asoka believed in, but it is evident that it was different from any form existing nowadays…Asoka’s reference to his “going forth to Sambodhi” in the 8th Rock Edict may indicate the very beginning of the concept of the bodhisattva…” |page=131-132, 141 |date=1982 |access-date=2018-04-01}}</ref> Asoka Rock Edict 1 dated to c. 257 BCE mentions the prohibition of animal sacrifices in Asoka’s [[Maurya Empire]] as well as his commitment to vegetarianism; however, whether the Sangha was vegetarian in part or in whole is unclear from these edicts. However, Asoka’s personal commitment to, and advocating of, vegetarianism suggests Early Buddhism (at the very least for the layperson) most likely already had a vegetarian tradition (the details of what that entailed besides not killing animals were not mentioned, and therefore are unknown.) <ref>{{cite web |url=http://asi.nic.in/asi_books/5282.pdf |website=Archaeological Survey of India |title=Asoka’s Edicts |last=Sen |first=Amulyachandra |quote=“Formerly in the kitchen of the Beloved of the gods, King Priyadarsin [another name for Asoka], many hundreds of thousands of animals were killed everyday for the sake of curry. But now when this Dharma-rescript is written, only three animals are being killed (everyday) for the sake of curry, (viz.) two peacocks (and) one deer, (and) the deer again not always. Even these three animals shall not be killed in the future.” |page=64 |date=1956 |access-date=2018-04-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160508090318/http://asi.nic.in/asi_books/5282.pdf |archive-date=2016-05-08 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
== Views of different schools == There is a divergence of views within Buddhism as to whether vegetarianism is required, with some schools of Buddhism rejecting such a requirement. The first precept in Buddhism is usually translated as "I undertake the precept to refrain from taking life". Some Buddhists see this as implying that Buddhists should avoid [[meat consumption]], whereas other Buddhists argue that this is untrue. Some Buddhists do strongly oppose meat-eating on the basis of scriptural injunctions against flesh-eating accorded in [[Mahayana sutras]].
=== Mahayana view === According to the ''[[Mahāyāna Mahāparinirvāṇa Sūtra]]'', a [[Mahayana sutras|Mahayana sutra]] purporting to give [[Gautama Buddha]]'s final teachings, the Buddha insisted that his followers should not eat any kind of meat or fish, even those not included in the 10 types, and that even vegetarian food that has been touched by meat should be washed before being eaten. Also, it is not permissible for the monk or nun just to pick out the non-meat portions of a diet and leave the rest: the whole meal must be rejected.<ref>[http://soulcurrymagazine.com/sc/buddhism-vegetarianism-non-vegetarianism.html Buddhism & Vegetarianism] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131021172541/http://soulcurrymagazine.com/sc/buddhism-vegetarianism-non-vegetarianism.html|date=2013-10-21}}</ref>
The ''[[Aṅgulimālīya Sūtra]]'' quotes a dialogue between Gautama Buddha and [[Manjushri]] on meat eating:
{{quote|Mañjuśrī asked, “Do Buddhas not eat meat because of the tathāgata-garbha ?” The Blessed One replied, “Mañjuśrī, that is so. There are no beings who have not been one’s mother, who have not been one’s sister through generations of wandering in beginningless and endless saṃsāra. Even one who is a dog has been one’s father, for the world of living beings is like a dancer. Therefore, one’s own flesh and the flesh of another are a single flesh, so Buddhas do not eat meat. “Moreover, Mañjuśrī, the dhātu of all beings is the dharmadhātu, so Buddhas do not eat meat because they would be eating the flesh of one single dhātu.”<ref>[http://www.webspawner.com/users/tathagatagarbha18/index.html Angulimaliya Sutra] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105032808/http://www.webspawner.com/users/tathagatagarbha18/index.html |date=November 5, 2013 }}</ref>}}
Certain [[Mahayana sutras]] do present the Buddha as very vigorously and unreservedly denouncing the eating of meat, mainly on the grounds that such an act is linked to the spreading of fear amongst [[Sentient beings (Buddhism)|sentient beings]] (who can allegedly sense the odour of death that lingers about the meat-eater and who consequently fear for their own lives) and violates the [[bodhisattva]]'s fundamental cultivation of compassion. Moreover, according to the Buddha in the [[Angulimaliya Sutra]], since all beings share the same "Dhatu" (spiritual Principle or Essence) and are intimately related to one another, killing and eating other sentient creatures is tantamount to a form of self-killing and cannibalism. The sutras which inveigh against meat-eating include the [[Nirvana Sutra]], the [[Shurangama Sutra]], the [[Brahmajala Sutra (Mahayana)|Brahmajala Sutra]], the [[Angulimaliya Sutra]], the Mahamegha Sutra, and the [[Lankavatara Sutra]]. In the [[Mahayana Mahaparinirvana Sutra]], which presents itself as the final elucidatory and definitive Mahayana teachings of the Buddha on the very eve of his death, the Buddha states that "the eating of meat extinguishes the seed of Great Kindness", adding that all and every kind of meat and fish consumption (even of animals found already dead) is prohibited by him. He specifically rejects the idea that monks who go out begging and receive meat from a donor should eat it: ". . . it should be rejected . . . I say that even meat, fish, game, dried hooves and scraps of meat left over by others constitutes an infraction . . . I teach the harm arising from meat-eating." The Buddha also predicts in this sutra that later monks will "hold spurious writings to be the authentic Dharma" and will concoct their own sutras and falsely claim that the Buddha allows the eating of meat, whereas he says he does not. A long passage in the Lankavatara Sutra shows the Buddha speaking out very forcefully against meat consumption and unequivocally in favor of vegetarianism, since the eating of the flesh of fellow sentient beings is said by him to be incompatible with the compassion that a Bodhisattva should strive to cultivate. This passage has been seen as questionable.<ref name="eight">[http://lirs.ru/do/lanka_eng/lanka-chapter-4.htm#chap8 The Lankavatara Sutra:Chapter Eight]</ref> In a translation by [[D. T. Suzuki]], a note is made that this section:
{{quote|This chapter on meat-eating is another later addition to the text, which was probably done earlier than the Rāvaṇa chapter....It is quite likely that meat-eating was practised more or less among the earlier Buddhists, which was made a subject of severe criticism by their opponents. The Buddhists at the time of the Laṅkāvatāra did not like it, hence this addition in which an apologetic tone is noticeable.<ref name="eight" />}}
In several other Mahayana scriptures, too (e.g., the Mahayana [[jatakas]]), the Buddha is seen clearly to indicate that meat-eating is undesirable and karmically unwholesome.
Some suggest that the rise of monasteries in Mahayana tradition to be a contributing factor in the emphasis on vegetarianism. In the monastery, food was prepared specifically for monks. In this context, large quantities of meat would have been specifically prepared (killed) for monks. Henceforth, when monks from the Indian geographical sphere of influence migrated to [[China]] from the year 65 CE on, they met followers who provided them with money instead of food. From those days onwards Chinese monastics, and others who came to inhabit northern countries, cultivated their own vegetable plots and bought food in the market.<ref>[http://www.kundalini.org.hk/sychinese/2_buddhism_p2.htm 佛教的本相 (下)]</ref><ref>[http://www.macau-buddhism.org/39/39-2f.htm 《學佛素食與健康長壽》]{{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727051833/http://www.macau-buddhism.org/39/39-2f.htm|date=July 27, 2011}}</ref> This remains the dominant practice in China, Vietnam and part of Korean Mahayanan temples.
Mahayana lay Buddhists often eat vegetarian diets on the vegetarian dates (齋期). There are different arrangement of the dates, from several days to three months in each year, in some traditions, the celebration of the bodhisattva [[Avalokitesvara]]'s birthday, enlightenment and leaving home days hold the highest importance to be vegetarian.<ref>[http://www.guoxue.com/discord/zz/dzps.htm 《地藏菩萨十斋日》]</ref>
=== Theravada View === The Buddha in the [[Anguttara Nikaya]] 3.38 '''Sukhamala Sutta''', before his enlightenment, describes his family being wealthy enough to provide non-vegetarian meals even to his servants. After becoming enlightened, he accepted any kind of food offered with respect as alms, including meat,<ref>[http://www.buddhanet.net/e-learning/dharmadata/fdd21.htm Dharma Data: Vegetarianism]</ref> but there is no reference of him eating meat during his seven years as an ascetic.
In the modern era, the passage cited below has been interpreted as allowing the consumption of meat ''if'' it is not specifically slaughtered for the recipient: {{quote|… meat should not be eaten under three circumstances: when it is seen or heard or suspected (that a living being has been purposely slaughtered for the eater); these, [[Jivaka]], are the three circumstances in which meat should not be eaten, Jivaka! I declare there are three circumstances in which meat can be eaten: when it is not seen or heard or suspected (that a living being has been purposely slaughtered for the eater); Jivaka, I say these are the three circumstances in which meat can be eaten. —'''Jivaka Sutta''', MN 55 '', [[unpublished]] translation by [[Sister Uppalavanna]]'' <ref>[http://www.vipassana.info/055-jivaka-e1.htm Jiivakasutta], this is an undated (and not formally published) translation by Sister Uppalavanna (b., 1886 as Else Buchholtz), originally distributed on the internet by the Sri Lankan website "Metta.LK".</ref>}}
Also in the Jivaka Sutta, Buddha instructs a monk or nun to accept, without any discrimination, whatever food is offered in receiving alms offered with good will, including meat, whereas the Buddha declares the meat trade to be [[Noble Eightfold Path|wrong livelihood]] in the '''Vanijja Sutta''', AN 5:177
{{quote|Monks, a lay follower should not engage in five types of business. Which five? Business in weapons, business in human beings, ''business in meat'', business in intoxicants, and business in poison. These are the five types of business that a lay follower should not engage in.<ref>[http://www.accesstoinsight.org/canon/sutta/anguttara/an05-177.html Vanijja Sutta: Business (Wrong Livelihood)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051119074312/http://www.accesstoinsight.org/canon/sutta/anguttara/an05-177.html |date=November 19, 2005 }}</ref>}}
But this is not, strictly speaking, a dietary rule. The Buddha, on one particular occasion, specifically refused suggestions by [[Devadatta]] to institute vegetarianism in the [[Sangha (Buddhism)|Sangha]].<ref>[http://www.buddhanet.net/budsas/ebud/ebdha069.htm#note4 "Buddhism and Vegetarianism, The Rationale for the Buddha's Views on the Consumption of Meat"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131007043230/http://www.buddhanet.net/budsas/ebud/ebdha069.htm |date=2013-10-07 }} by Dr V. A. Gunasekara" 'The rule of vegetarianism was the fifth of a list of rules which Devadatta had proposed to the Buddha. Devadatta was the founder of the tapasa movement in Buddhism and his special rules involved ascetic and austere practices (forest-dwelling, wearing only rags, etc). The Buddha rejected all the proposed revisions of Devadatta, and it was in this context that he reiterated the tikoiparisuddha rule. (On this see the author's Western Buddhism and a Theravada heterodoxy, BSQ Tracts on Buddhism'</ref>
In the Amagandha Sutta in the Sutta Nipata, a vegetarian Brahmin confronts [[Kassapa Buddha]] (a previous Buddha before Gautama Buddha) in regard to the evil of eating meat. The Buddha countered the argument by listing acts which cause real moral defilement and then at the end of the verse, he emphasized that the consumption of meat is not equivalent to those acts. ("... this is the stench giving defilement, not the consumption of meat").
:"[t]aking life, beating, wounding, binding, stealing, lying, deceiving, worthless knowledge, adultery; this is stench. Not the eating of meat." ('''Amagandha Sutta''').
There were monastic guidelines prohibiting consumption of 10 types of meat: that of humans, [[Elephant meat|elephants]], horses, dogs, snakes, lions, tigers, leopards, bears and hyenas. This is because these animals can be provoked by the smell of the flesh of their own kind, or because eating of such flesh would generate a bad reputation for the Sangha.
Paul Breiter, a student of [[Ajahn Chah]], states that some bhikkhus in [[Thai Forest Tradition|Thailand]] choose to be vegetarian and that [[Ajahn Sumedho]] encouraged supporters to prepare vegetarian food for the temple.<ref>{{cite book|last=Breiter|first=Paul|title=Venerable Father|publisher=Paraview Special Editions|page=xii|year=2004|ISBN=1-931044-81-3}}</ref>
In the Pali Canon, Buddha once explicitly refused suggestion by [[Devadatta]] to institute vegetarianism in the monks' [[Vinaya]].<ref>{{cite book | last = Phelps | first = Norm | authorlink = Norm Phelps | title = The Great Compassion: Buddhism & Animal Rights | year = 2004 | publisher = Lantern Books | location = New York | pages = 76 | quote =monks would have to accept whatever they found in their begging bowls, including meat, provided that they had not seen, had not heard, and had no reason to suspect that the animal had been killed so that the meat could be given to them. | isbn = 1-59056-069-8}}</ref>
=== Vajrayana === Some Vajrayana practitioners both drink alcohol <ref>[http://www.elephantjournal.com/2009/03/mindful-drinking-vajrayana-tradition-alcohol-and-buddhism/ Mindful Drinking?]</ref><ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/lodro-rinzler/buddhism-and-alcohol-what_b_695369.html Buddhism and Alcohol]</ref> and eat meat.<ref>[http://www.universaldharma.com/pages/dharma%20pages/msdway.html The Maitreya Sangha Way] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717163515/http://www.universaldharma.com/pages/dharma%20pages/msdway.html |date=July 17, 2011 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.rinpoche.com/teachings/nomeat.htm?page_id=52 Teaching on Not Eating Meat by His Holiness 17th Gyalwang Karmapa]</ref> Many traditions of the [[Ganachakra]] which is a type of [[Panchamakara]] [[puja (Buddhism)|puja]] prescribed the offering and ingestion of meat and alcohol, although this practice is now often only a symbolic one, with no actual meat or alcohol ingested.
One of the most important [[tertön]]s of [[Tibet]], [[Jigme Lingpa]], wrote of his great compassion for animals: {{quote|Of all his merit-making, Jigme Lingpa was most proud of his feelings of compassion for animals; he says that this is the best part of his entire life story. He writes of his sorrow when he witnessed the butchering of animals by humans. He often bought and set free animals about to be slaughtered (a common Buddhist act). He ‘changed the perception’ of others, when he once caused his followers to save a female yak from being butchered, and he continually urged his disciples to forswear the killing of animals.<ref>[http://www.serv-online.org/Eileen-Weintraub.htm Life as a Vegetarian Tibetan Buddhist Practitioner]</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=lmqSoNsRSx8C Apparitions of the Self: The Secret Autobiographies of a Tibetan Visionary]</ref>}}
In ''The Life of Shabkar, the Autobiography of a Tibetan Yogin'', [[Shabkar Tsokdruk Rangdrol]] wrote: {{quote|Above all, you must constantly train your mind to be loving, compassionate, and filled with [[Bodhicitta]]. You must give up eating meat, for it is very wrong to eat the flesh of our parent sentient beings.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=bXAUkoM0esMC ''The life of Shabkar: the autobiography of a Tibetan yogin''] page 541</ref>}}
The [[14th Dalai Lama]] and other esteemed lamas invite their audiences to adopt vegetarianism when they can. When asked in recent years what he thinks of vegetarianism, the 14th Dalai Lama has said: "It is wonderful. We must absolutely promote vegetarianism."<ref>''Buddha Heart, Buddha Mind,'' 2000</ref> The Dalai Lama tried becoming a vegetarian and promoted vegetarianism.<ref>[http://www.godsdirectcontact.org.tw/eng/news/160/vg6.htm Vegetarian Awakening in the Himalayas]</ref> In 1999, it was published that the Dalai Lama would only be vegetarian every other day and partakes of meat regularly.<ref>[http://www.tribuneindia.com/1999/99jan17/sunday/speaking.htm To be or not to be a vegetarian]</ref> When he is in Dharamsala, he is vegetarian, but not necessarily when he is outside Dharamsala.<ref>[http://www.dalailama.com/page.52.htm A Routine Day of HH The Dalai Lama] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090224214736/http://www.dalailama.com/page.52.htm |date=February 24, 2009 }}</ref> Paul McCartney has taken him to task for this and wrote to him to urge him to return to strict vegetarianism, but "[The Dalai Lama] replied [to me] saying that his doctors had told him he needed [meat], so I wrote back saying they were wrong."<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/faith/article2099953.ece | work=The Times | location=London | title=Sir Paul McCartney's advice to the Dalai Lama | date=15 December 2008 | accessdate=27 April 2010}}</ref>
[[Tenzin Wangyal Rinpoche]] became vegetarian in 2008.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3VqgIJ8AObA]</ref>
[[Arjia Rinpoche]] became vegetarian in 1999.<ref>[http://www.shabkar.org/teachers/tibetanbuddhism/arjia_rinpoche.htm Arjia Lobsang Thubten Rinpoche (1950 - )]</ref>
On 3 January 2007, one of the two 17th [[Karmapa]], [[Urgyen Trinley Dorje]], strongly urged vegetarianism upon his students, saying that generally, in his view, it was very important in the Mahayana not to eat meat and that even in Vajrayana students should not eat meat: <blockquote> There are many great masters and very great realized beings in [[India]] and there have been many great realized beings in [[Tibet]] also, but they are not saying, "I'm realized, therefore I can do anything; I can eat meat and drink alcohol." It's nothing like that. It should not be like that. According to the [[Kagyupa]] school, we have to see what the great masters of the past, the past lamas of Kagyupas, did and said about eating meat. The Drikung Shakpa [sp?] Rinpoche, master of Drikungpa, said like this, "My students, whomever are eating or using meat and calling it tsokhor or [[Ganachakra|tsok]], then these people are completely deserting me and going against the dharma." I can't explain each of these things, but he said that anybody that is using meat and saying it is something good, this is completely against the dharma and against me and they completely have nothing to do with dharma. He said it very, very strongly.<ref>[http://www.shabkar.org/download/pdf/Talk_on_Vegetarianism.pdf Talk on Vegetarianism] by Orgyen Trinle Dorje, Karmapa XVII</ref></blockquote>
== Common practices ==
=== Theravada === In the modern world, attitudes toward vegetarianism vary by location. In [[Sri Lanka]] and the [[Theravada]] countries of [[South East Asia]], monks are obliged by the [[vinaya]] to accept almost any food that is offered to them, including meat unless they suspect the meat was slaughtered specifically for them.
=== Chinese, Korean, Vietnamese, and Taiwanese traditions === In [[China]], [[Korea]], [[Vietnam]], [[Taiwan]] and their respective diaspora communities monks and nuns are expected to abstain from meat and, traditionally, eggs and dairy, in addition to the [[fetid]] vegetables – traditionally [[garlic]], ''[[Allium chinense]]'', [[asafoetida]], [[shallot]], and ''[[Allium victorialis]]'' (victory onion or mountain leek), although in modern times this rule is often interpreted to include other vegetables of the [[Allium|onion]] [[genus]], as well as [[coriander]] – this is called pure vegetarianism (純素, chúnsù). Pure Vegetarianism is Indic in origin and is still practiced in India by some adherents of Dharmic religions such as Jainism and in the case of Hinduism, lacto-vegetarianism with the additional abstaintion of pungent or fetid vegetables. A minority of Buddhist lay believers are year-long vegetarians in the monastic way. Many lay followers followed monastic style vegetarianism on Lunar New Year's Eve, Saints days and ancestral feast days as well as the 1st and 15th day of the lunar calendar. Some lay followers also followed monastic style vegetarianism on the six-day，ten-day， Guan-yin (Avalokitesvara) vegetarian, etc., set lunar calendar schedule. Other Buddhist lay-followers also follow less stringent forms of vegetarianism. Most Buddhist lay-followers however are not vegetarians. Some [[Zhaijiao]] lay adherents also do not eat any meat.
=== Japanese traditions === {{see also|Shōjin ryōri}} Japan initially received [[Chinese Buddhism]] in 6th century. In the 9th century, [[Emperor Saga]] made a decree prohibiting meat consumption except fish and birds. This remained the dietary habit of Japanese until the introduction of European dietary customs in the 19th century.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}} Again around the 9th century, two Japanese monks ([[Kūkai]] and [[Saichō]]) introduced Vajrayana Buddhism into Japan and this soon became the dominant Buddhism among the nobility. In particular, Saichō, who founded the [[Tendai]] sect of Japanese Buddhism, reduced the number of vinaya code to 66. (Enkai 円戒) During the 12th century, a number of monks from [[Tendai]] sects founded new schools ([[Zen]], [[Pure Land]]) and de-emphasised vegetarianism, [[Nichiren Buddhism]] today likewise de-emphasises vegetarianism. However, Nichiren himself practiced vegetarianism.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}} Zen does tend generally to look favourably upon vegetarianism. The [[Shingon]] sect founded by Kūkai recommends vegetarianism and requires it at certain times, but it is not always strictly required for monks and nuns.
=== Tibetan traditions === In [[Tibet]], where vegetables have been historically very scarce, and the adopted vinaya was the Nikaya Sarvāstivāda, vegetarianism is very rare, although the [[Dalai Lama]], the [[Karmapa]], and other esteemed lamas invite their audiences to adopt vegetarianism whenever they can. [[Chatral Rinpoche]] in particular stated that anyone who wished to be his student must be vegetarian. Contradictory to the compassionate Tibetan Buddhist traditions in which a sanctity of life, both human and animal, is cherished, meat is often consumed as a form of sustenance due to lack of vegetation readily available. For example, Tibetan medicine emphasizes the necessity to acquire and sustain a balance between the bodily fluids of wind (rlung), phlegm (bad kan), and bile (mkhns), in which a meatless diet would disturb and eventually lead to fatigue. The 18th century Tibetan religious leader Jigmé Lingpa suggested that Tibetan Buddhists who wish to consume meat, but also do not want to sacrifice their religious beliefs, should recite a prayer over their plate of meat in order to purify it before it is consumed. This is said to create a favorable interconnection between the consumer and the animal, assisting it to attain a finer rebirth.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Barstow|first1=Geoffrey|title=Buddhism between abstinence and indulgence: vegetarianism in the life and works of Jigmé Lingpa|journal=Journal of Buddhist Ethics|date=1 January 2013|volume=20|pages=75–104|url=http://blogs.dickinson.edu.authenticate.library.duq.edu/buddhistethics/|accessdate=4 February 2015}}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>

(2004). ''The Great Compassion: Buddhism and Animal Rights.'' [[Lantern Books]]. *Page, Tony (1998), ''Buddhism and Animals'' (Nirvana Publications, London) *Rangdrol, Shabkar Natshok. (Translated by Padmakara Translation Group.) ''Food of Bodhisattvas: Buddhist Teachings on Abstaining from Meat.'' Shambhala Publications, 2004.

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2011}} {{Multiple image | header = ''[[Killer whale|Orcinus orca]]'' and its range | width = 240 | image1 = Killerwhales jumping.jpg | image2 = Killer Whale Range Map.svg | direction = vertical }} In [[biogeography]], a [[taxon]] is said to have a '''cosmopolitan distribution''' if its [[range (biology)|range]] extends across all or most of the world in appropriate [[habitat]]s. Such a taxon is said to exhibit cosmopolitanism or cosmopolitism. The opposite extreme is [[endemism]].
==Related terms and concepts== The term '''pandemism''' also is in use, but not all authors are consistent in the sense in which they use the term; some speak of pandemism mainly in referring to diseases and [[pandemic]]s, and some as a term intermediate between endemism and cosmopolitanism, in effect regarding pandemism as '''subcosmopolitanism'''. This means near cosmopolitanism, but with major gaps in the [[species distribution|distribution]], say, complete absence from Australia.<ref name="Simpson2010">{{cite book|author=Michael G. Simpson|title=Plant Systematics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dj8KRImgyf4C&pg=PA720|date=19 July 2010|publisher=Academic Press|isbn=978-0-08-092208-9|pages=720–}}</ref><ref name="HarperServais2014">{{cite book|author1=D. A. T. Harper|author2=T. Servais|title=Early Palaeozoic Biogeography and Palaeogeography|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mIWhAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA31|date=27 January 2014|publisher=Geological Society of London|isbn=978-1-86239-373-8|pages=31–}}</ref> Terminology varies, and there is some debate whether the true opposite of endemism is pandemism or cosmopolitism.<ref name="Rapoport2013">{{cite book|author=Eduardo H Rapoport|title=Areography: Geographical Strategies of Species|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ePHfBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA251|date=22 October 2013|publisher=Elsevier|isbn=978-1-4831-5277-6|pages=251–}}</ref>
==Aspects and degrees== The term "cosmopolitan distribution" usually should not be taken literally, because it often is applied loosely in various contexts. Commonly the intention is not to include polar regions, extreme altitudes, oceans, deserts, or small, isolated islands.<ref>{{cite book|title=Encyclopedia of Ecology and Environmental Management|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JKTeiqPBpM4C&pg=PA164|date=15 July 2009|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-1-4443-1324-6|pages=164–}}</ref> For example, the [[housefly]] is nearly as cosmopolitan as any animal species, but it is neither oceanic nor polar in its distribution.<ref name="RussellOtranto2013">{{cite book|author1=Richard C. Russell|author2=Domenico Otranto|author3=Richard L. Wall|title=The Encyclopedia of Medical and Veterinary Entomology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9QfhF_wQSV4C&pg=PA157|year=2013|publisher=CABI|isbn=978-1-78064-037-2|pages=157–}}</ref> Similarly, the term "cosmopolitan weed" implies no more than that the plant in question occurs on all continents except [[Antarctica]]; it is not meant to suggest that the species is present in all regions of every continent.
==Oceanic and terrestrial== Another concept in [[biogeography]] is that of [[Oceanography|oceanic]] cosmopolitanism and endemism. Although there is a temptation to regard the [[World Ocean]] as a medium without biological boundaries, this is far from reality; many physical and biological barriers interfere with either the spread or continued residence of many species. For example, temperature gradients prevent free migration of tropical species between the Atlantic and Indian-plus-Pacific oceans, even though there is open passage past continental masses such as the Americas and Africa/Eurasia. Again, as far as many species are concerned, the [[Southern Ocean]] and the Northern marine regions are completely isolated from each other by the intolerable temperatures of the tropical regions. In the light of such considerations, it is no surprise to find that endemism and cosmopolitanism are quite as marked in the oceans as on land.
==Ecological delimitation== Another aspect of cosmopolitanism is that of ecological limitations. A species that is apparently cosmopolitan because it occurs in all oceans might in fact occupy only [[littoral zone|littoral zones]], or only particular ranges of depths, or only [[Estuary|estuaries]], for example. Analogously, [[Ecoregion#Terrestrial|terrestrial]] species might be present only in forests, or mountainous regions, or sandy [[arid]] regions or the like. Such distributions might be patchy, or extended, but narrow. Factors of such a nature are taken widely for granted, so they seldom are mentioned explicitly in mentioning cosmopolitan distributions.
==Regional and temporal variation in populations== Cosmopolitanism of a particular species or variety should not be confused with cosmopolitanism of higher taxa. For example, the family [[Antlion|Myrmeleontidae]] is cosmopolitan in the sense that every continent except Antarctica is home to some indigenous species within the Myrmeleontidae, but nonetheless no one species, nor even genus, of the Myrmeleontidae is cosmopolitan. Conversely, partly as a result of human introduction of unnatural [[Beekeeping|apiculture]] to the New World, ''[[western honey bee|Apis mellifera]]'' probably is the only cosmopolitan member of its family; the rest of the family [[Apidae]] have modest distributions.
Even where a cosmopolitan population is recognised as a single species, such as indeed ''Apis mellifera'', there generally will be variation between regional sub-populations. Such variation commonly is at the level of [[subspecies]], [[Variety (botany)|varieties]] or [[Polymorphism (biology)|morphs]], whereas some variation is too slight or inconsistent for formal recognition.
For an example of subspecific variation, consider the so-called "[[Africanized bee|African killer bee]]", which is the subspecies ''[[African bee|Apis mellifera scutellata]]'', and the [[African bee|Cape bee]], which is the subspecies ''[[African bee|Apis mellifera capensis]]''; both of them are in the same cosmopolitan species ''Apis mellifera'', but their ranges barely overlap.
Other cosmopolitan species, such as the [[osprey]] and [[house sparrow]], present similar examples, but in yet other species there are less familiar complications: some migratory birds such as the [[Arctic tern]] occur from the Arctic to the [[Southern Ocean]], but at any one season of the year they are likely to be largely in passage or concentrated at only one end of the range. Also, some such species breed only at one end of the range. Seen purely as an aspect of cosmopolitanism, such distributions could be seen as temporal, seasonal variations.
Other complications of cosmopolitanism on a planet too large for local populations to interbreed routinely with each other, lead to genetic effects such as [[ring species]], for example in the ''[[Larus]]'' gulls.<ref name="Kunz2013">{{cite book|author=Werner Kunz|title=Do Species Exist: Principles of Taxonomic Classification|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xQxwAAAAQBAJ&pg=PT211|date=2 August 2013|publisher=Wiley|isbn=978-3-527-66426-9|pages=211–}}</ref> They also lead to the formation of [[Cline (biology)|clines]] such as in [[Drosophila]].<ref name="KrimbasPowell1992">{{cite book|author1=Costas B. Krimbas|author2=Jeffrey R. Powell|title=Drosophila Inversion Polymorphism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PLSPhg3KPGgC&pg=PA23|date=21 August 1992|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=978-0-8493-6547-8|pages=23–}}</ref>
==Ancient and modern==
Cosmopolitan distributions can be observed both in extinct and extant species. For example, ''[[Lystrosaurus]]'' was cosmopolitan in the Early Triassic after a mass extinction.<ref name="SahneyBenton2008">{{cite journal | url=http://rspb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/275/1636/759.full.pdf |author1=Sahney, S. |author2=Benton, M. J. | year=2008 | title=Recovery from the most profound mass extinction of all time | journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences | doi=10.1098/rspb.2007.1370 | volume = 275 | pages = 759–65|format=PDF | pmid=18198148 | issue=1636 | pmc=2596898}}</ref>
In the modern world, the [[killer whale]] has a cosmopolitan distribution, extending over most of the Earth's [[ocean]]s. The wasp ''[[Copidosoma floridanum]]'' is another example, as it is found around the world. Other examples include [[human]]s, [[cat]]s, [[dog]]s, [[orchid]]s, the foliose [[lichen]] ''[[Parmelia sulcata]]'', and the [[Mollusca|mollusc]] genus ''[[Mytilus (bivalve)|Mytilus]]''.<ref name="Spellerberg">{{cite book |editor1=Ian F. Spellerberg |editor2=John William David Sawyer |year=1999 |title=An Introduction to Applied Biogeography |publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] |isbn=978-0-521-45712-5 |chapter=Ecological patterns and types of species distribution |pages=108–132 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=j3bpQzDz1xkC&pg=PA110}}</ref> The term can also apply to some diseases. It may result from a broad range of environmental tolerances<ref>{{cite journal |author=S. Kustanowich |year=1963 |title=Distribution of planktonic foraminifera in surface sediments of the south-west Pacific |journal=[[New Zealand Journal of Geology and Geophysics]] |volume=6 |issue=4 |pages=534–565 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_SA4AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA534 |doi=10.1080/00288306.1963.10420065}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=The Micropalaeontology of Oceans: Proceedings of the Symposium held in Cambridge from 10 to 17 September 1967 under the title 'Micropalaeontology of Marine Bottom Sediments' |editor1=B. M. Funnell |editor2=W. R. Riedel |publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] |year=1971 |isbn=978-0-521-18748-0 |chapter=The distribution of marine dinoflagellates in relation to physical and chemical conditions |author=D. B. Williams |pages=91–95 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cNutoYzqkY8C&pg=PA93}}</ref> or from rapid [[Biological dispersal|dispersal]] compared to the time needed for [[evolution]].<ref>{{cite book |editor1=Patrick E. O'Sullivan |editor2=Colin S. Reynolds |year=2005 |title=Limnology and Limnetic Ecology |volume=1 |series=The Lakes Handbook |publisher=[[Wiley-Blackwell]] |isbn=978-0-632-04797-0 |chapter=Phytoplankton |author=Judit Padisák |pages=251–308 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jsg4Cwp5-C0C&pg=PA285}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Ecoregion]] * [[Gondwanan distribution]] * [[Holarctic]] * [[Pantropical]]

{{Use MDY dates|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Daniel Yergin | image = Daniel_Yergin_-_World_Economic_Forum_Annual_Meeting_2012.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = At the [[World Economic Forum]] in 2012 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1947|2|06}} | birth_place = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], [[United States]] | nationality = [[United States|American]] | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Author, historian, educator, energy analyst | net worth = | residence = [[Washington, DC]] | alma mater = [[Yale University]]
[[Trinity College, Cambridge]] | awards = [[Pulitzer Prize]] | website = {{URL|www.danielyergin.com}} }} '''Daniel Howard Yergin''' (born February 6, 1947) is an American author, speaker, energy expert, and economic historian. Yergin is vice chairman of [[IHS Markit]], a research and information company which absorbed his own energy research consultancy [[Cambridge Energy Research Associates]] in 2004. He has authored or co-authored several books on energy and world economics, including the [[Pulitzer Prize]]-winning ''[[The Prize: The Epic Quest for Oil, Money, and Power]]'' (1991) and ''[[The Quest: Energy, Security, and the Remaking of the Modern World]]'' (2011). Yergin's articles and [[op-eds]] on energy, history, and the economy have been published in publications such as ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', ''[[The New York Times]]'', ''[[The Washington Post]]'', and ''[[The Financial Times]]''. All of Yergin's books have been drafted in long-hand. Currently a director on entities such as the [[Council on Foreign Relations]] and the [[United States Energy Association]], he is also a trustee of the [[Brookings Institution]] and a long-term advisor to several U.S. administrations. He is also chairman of the annual [[CERAWeek]] energy conference. ==Early life and education== Daniel Howard Yergin was born on February 6, 1947{{cite news |last= |first= |date=October 26, 2011 |title=A look at historian and author Daniel Yergin |url=http://archive.boston.com/yourtown/cambridge/articles/2011/10/26/a_look_at_historian_and_author_daniel_yergin/ | work=[[Associated Press]] |location= |access-date=December 22, 2017}} in [[Los Angeles, California]]. His father Irving Yergin worked at [[Warner Brothers]] and was editor of ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' and a former journalist in [[Chicago]], while his mother Naomi Yergin was a sculptor and painter. Yergin attended [[Beverly Hills High School]].{{cite news |last=Parrish |first=Michael |date=January 9, 1993 |title=He Knows Oil : Daniel Yergin Built a Company and Penned a Best-Selling History |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1993-01-09/business/fi-1042_1_daniel-yergin | work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |location=Los Angeles, California, United States |access-date=December 22, 2017}}Redburn, Tom. [https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/652246772.html?dids=652246772:652246772&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&date=Aug+19%2C+1979&author=TOM+REDBURN&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc='Energy+Future'+Goes+Beyond+Ivory+Tower&pqatl=google "'Energy Future' Goes Beyond Ivory Tower"], ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', August 19, 1979. Retrieved December 15, 2007. "Fifteen years ago, Daniel Yergin left Beverly Hills High School to attend Yale University and, except for summer jobs and brief visits, he hasn't been back here since." He received his [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] from [[Yale University]] in 1968,{{cite news |last= |first= |date=April 22, 2013 |title=A Conversation with Daniel Yergin |url=http://www.thenewjournalatyale.com/2013/04/a-conversation-with-daniel-yergin/ | work=[[The New Journal]] |location= |access-date=December 23, 2017}} where he wrote for the ''[[Yale Daily News]]'' and was founder of ''[[The New Journal]]'' in 1967. He received his [[M.A.]] in 1970 and his [[PhD]] in [[international history]] from [[Cambridge University]], where he was a [[Marshall Scholarship|Marshall Scholar]]. While at Cambridge he wrote for various British magazines as well as ''[[The Atlantic]]'', where he was a contributing editor,{{cite news |last=Clendinen |first=Dudley |date=October 22, 1982 |title=In Boston, Days of Literary Renewal |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/22/us/in-boston-days-of-literary-renewal.html?mcubz=1 | work=[[The New York Times]] |location= New York City, new York, United States|access-date=December 23, 2017}} and ''[[The New York Times Magazine]]''. He has honorary doctorates from [[Dartmouth College]],{{cite news|date=April 15, 2016 |title=Daniel Yergin to receive honorary doctorate from Dartmouth College |url=http://www.ogfj.com/articles/2016/04/daniel-yergin-to-receive-honorary-doctorate-from-dartmouth-college.html | work=Oil and Gas Financial Journal |location= |access-date=December 22, 2017}} [[Colorado School of Mines]],{{cite news |date= |title=Commencement 2008 |url=http://magazine.mines.edu/2008/Summer/Features/commencement_2008.html|work=Colorado School of Mines |location=Colorado, United States |access-date=December 22, 2017}} [[University of Houston]], and the [[University of Missouri]].{{Citation|year= |title=Daniel Yergin |publisher=[[CNBC]] |url=https://www.cnbc.com/daniel-yergin/|accessdate=December 22, 2017 }} ==Career== ===1970s=== Early in his career, Yergin worked as a contributing editor for ''[[New York Magazine]]''. Through 1980 he was a lecturer at the [[Harvard Business School]] and, until 1985, a lecturer at Harvard's [[Kennedy School of Government]]. Yergin's first book, ''Shattered Peace: The Origins of the Cold War and the National Security State'' (1977), was partly based upon his PhD dissertation and focused on the origins of the [[Cold War]]. It was named "best book of the year" by the National Historical Society.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} In the mid-1970s, while a post-doctoral fellow,{{cite news |last=Shapiro |first=Tamar A. |date=April 11, 1992 |title=Yergin Receives Pulitzer Prize |url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article/1992/4/11/yergin-receives-pulitzer-prize-pcambridge-resident/ | work=[[The Crimson]] |location= |access-date=December 23, 2017}} he began to take a particular interest in energy in his writing. Basing the book on four years of research, with [[Robert B. Stobaugh]] he co-authored and co-edited ''Energy Future: The Report of the Energy Project at the Harvard Business School'' in 1979.{{cite news|last=Klemesrud|first=Judy|title=Energy Future|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1979/11/18/111755627.pdf|accessdate=March 4, 2012|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=November 18, 1979}} According to the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', the book “caused a considerable stir with its optimistic view of the possibilities of energy conservation and such alternative sources as solar power." It proved to be a ''[[The New York Times]]'' bestseller, ultimately selling 300,000 copies in six languages. Within its first year of release, Yergin and Stobaugh were called to Washington D.C. several times to testify before Congressional committees. He also advised [[James Schlesinger]], the first US energy secretary, around the time of the [[Iranian revolution]]. According to ''[[Reuters]]'', ”since then he has given advice to every administration.” ===1980s-1990s=== He founded [[Cambridge Energy Research Associates]] with [[CERAWeek|Jamey Rosenfield]] (CERA) in 1982 with the purchase of a $2 file cabinet from [[The Salvation Army]].{{Cite web|url=http://investor.ihs.com/phoenix.zhtml?c=188457&p=irol-EventDetails&EventId=5203228|title=Dan Yergin at IHS Investor Day - Slide 88 at 01:30:15|website=investor.ihs.com|access-date=2016-06-23}}{{cite news|last=Ringle|first=Ken|title=Daniel Yergin, Turning a Prophet; How a Historian Became a Market Guru And Hit the Jackpot|url=http://www.lexisnexis.com/lnacui2api/api/version1/getDocCui?lni=3SDT-F6S0-007D-J2DJ&csi=8157&hl=t&hv=t&hnsd=f&hns=t&hgn=t&oc=00240&perma=true|accessdate=March 4, 2012|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=April 9, 1998}} With Yergin as president, the energy research and consulting firm was created as a "quasi think-tank and source of energy industry analysis.” Yergin is arguably best known for his fourth book, ''[[The Prize: The Epic Quest for Oil, Money, and Power]]'' (1991). It became a number-one bestseller that won the [[Pulitzer Prize for General Non-Fiction]] in 1992 and the Eccles Prize for the best book on economics for a general audience,{{cite news|title=1992 Pulitzer Prize Winners and Their Works in Journalism and the Arts|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/04/08/nyregion/1992-pulitzer-prize-winners-and-their-works-in-journalism-and-the-arts.html?scp=1&sq=%22The%20Prize%22%20%20Yergin%20wins%20pulitzer%20for%20general%20non-fiction&st=cse|accessdate=March 4, 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=April 8, 1992}} selling around 700,000 copies in 17 languages.{{Citation |last=Yergin |first=Daniel |date=December 23, 2008 |title=The Prize: The Epic Quest for Oil, Money & Power - Description |publisher=Free Press |publication-place= |page= |url=https://www.amazon.com/Prize-Epic-Quest-Money-Power/dp/1439110123 |accessdate=December 23, 2017 }} The book was adapted into a [[PBS]]/[[BBC]] series seen by around 100 million viewers both domestically and internationally, with Yergin as the principal storyteller.[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0278873/ The Prize on PBS - credits and cast listing on IMDB] His next book was ''Russia 2010 and What It Means for the World'' (1993), written with [[Thane Gustafson]], which provided scenarios for the development of Russia after the collapse of the Soviet Union.{{cite news |last1=Yergin |first1=Daniel |last2=Gustafson |first2=Thane |date=April 1994 |title=Russia 2010 and What It Means for the World |url=https://www.foreignaffairs.com/reviews/capsule-review/1994-03-01/russia-2010-and-what-it-means-world | work=[[Foreign Affairs]] |location= |access-date=December 22, 2017}} ===2000s-2010s=== His 2002 book ''The Commanding Heights: The Battle for the World Economy'', written with [[Joseph Stanislaw]], described in narrative form the struggle over the "frontier" between governments and markets and the rise of globalization. In the "first major PBS series on business in more than a decade,” he led the team that created a prize-winning six-hour{{Citation |title=Board Member Emeritus, New America; Vice Chairman, IHS |publisher=[[New America (newspaper)|New America]] |url=https://www.newamerica.org/our-people/daniel-yergin/ |accessdate=December 23, 2017 }} PBS/BBC television series based on the book, serving as executive producer and co-writer{{Citation |title=Credits - Commanding Heights |publisher=PBS |publication-place=United States |url=http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/commandingheights/lo/credits/ |accessdate=December 23, 2017 }} and interviewing individuals such as [[Bill Clinton]], [[Dick Cheney]], [[Vicente Fox]], and [[Mikhail Gorbachev]].{{cite news |date=2002 |title=Commanding Heights: The Battle for the World Economy |url=https://www.wired.com/2002/04/commanding-heights-the-battle-for-the-world-economy/ | work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |location= |access-date=December 22, 2017}} {{external media | width = 210px | align = right | headerimage= | video1 = [https://www.c-span.org/video/?16032-1/prize-epic-quest-oil-money-power ''Booknotes'' interview with Yergin on ''The Prize''], [[C-SPAN]]}} CERA was acquired by the information company [[IHS Inc.]] in 2004, with Yergin becoming an executive of the combined company and remaining chairman of CERA.{{cite news |last=Morrison |first= Kevin |date=September 3, 2004 |title=ERA sold to IHS Energy |url=https://www.ft.com/content/415c9c16-fdb4-11d8-9dca-00000e2511c8 | work=[[The Financial Times]] |location=London, United Kingdom |access-date=December 23, 2017}} Described as a sequel to his book ''The Prize,'' Yergin's ''[[The Quest: Energy, Security, and the Remaking of the Modern World]]'' (2011) continued his history of the global oil industry but also addressed energy security, natural gas, electric power, climate change and the search for renewable sources of energy.{{cite journal |url=http://www.nybooks.com/articles/archives/2012/apr/26/what-will-it-take-save-earth |title=What Will It Take to Save the Earth? |date=April 26, 2012 |authorlink=Joel E. Cohen |first=Joel E. |last=Cohen |journal=[[The New York Review of Books]]}} Like his previous books, it was drafted in long-hand.{{cite news|last=Khan|first=Chris|title=Yergin: Only politics can threaten energy supplies|url=http://www.chron.com/business/article/Yergin-Only-politics-can-threaten-energy-supplies-2237263.php|accessdate=March 4, 2012|newspaper=[[The Associated Press]]|date=October 27, 2011}} In 2011 it was shortlisted for the [[Financial Times and McKinsey Business Book of the Year Award]].{{cite web |url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/b91da7b4-deb1-11e0-a228-00144feabdc0.html#axzz1Y22DkBsF |title=2011 shortlist |work=Financial Times|location=London, United Kingdom |date=14 September 2011 |accessdate=30 May 2012}} In July 2012, he became vice chairman of IHS.{{Citation |last= |first= |date=July 12, 2012 |title=IHS Names Daniel Yergin Vice Chairman |publisher=NEMA press release |publication-place= |page= |url=http://www.nema.org/news/Pages/IHS-Names-Daniel-Yergin-Vice-Chairman.aspx|accessdate= }} IHS then merged in 2016 with [[Markit]] to become [[IHS Markit]],{{cite news |date=July 13, 2016 |title=IHS Markit Rings Opening Bell at Nasdaq, Unveils New Logo |url=http://press.ihs.com/press-release/corporate/ihs-markit-rings-opening-bell-nasdaq-unveils-new-logo | work=IHS Markit |location= |access-date=December 22, 2017}} with Yergin remaining IHS vice chairman.{{cite web|title=IHS Executives|url=http://www.ihs.com/about/executives.asp|publisher=IHS Inc.|accessdate=March 4, 2012}} As of 2017, he remains chairman of IHS Markit’s annual [[CERAWeek]] energy conference.{{cite news |last=Yedlin |first=Deborah |date=March 6, 2017 |title=Yedlin: CERAWeek conference opens with renewed optimism |url=http://calgaryherald.com/business/energy/yedlin-ceraweek-conference-opens-with-renewed-optimism | work=[[Calgary Herald]] |location=Calgary, Alberta, Canada |access-date=December 23, 2017}} ==Viewpoints and research== [[File:2014 International Seapower Symposium (15277793135).jpg|thumb|250px|Yergin at the 2014 International Seapower Symposium]] Yergin's articles[http://www.livemint.com/2007/05/01171220/A-price-tag-to-growth--Daniel.html A Price Tag to Growth], ''[[Mint (newspaper)|LiveMint]]'', February 23, 2007 and [[op-eds]] on energy, history, and the economy have been published in a variety of publications, including ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'',[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB115508164240330491 Crisis in the Pipeline], Daniel Yergin, ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', August 10, 2006 ''[[The New York Times]]'',[https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/21/books/the-quest-by-daniel-yergin-review.html Visions of an Age When Oil Isn’t King] ''[[The New York Times]]'', September 20, 2011 ''[[Foreign Affairs (magazine)|Foreign Affairs]]'', ''[[The Washington Post]]'',{{cite news |last=Yergin |first=Daniel |date=October 28, 2011 |title=Oil’s new world order |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/daniel-yergin-for-the-future-of-oil-look-to-the-americas-not-the-middle-east/2011/10/18/gIQAxdDw7L_story.html | work=[[The Washington Post]] |location=[[Washington, D.C.]], [[United States]] |access-date=December 23, 2017}} the ''[[Financial Times]]'',{{cite news |last=Yergin |first=Daniel |date=January 26, 2016 |title=Oil prices are at the mercy of geopolitics |url=https://www.ft.com/content/5c6e1840-bed2-11e5-9fdb-87b8d15baec2 | work=[[Financial Times]]|location=London, United Kingdom |access-date=December 23, 2017}} and ''[[Forbes]]''.{{cite news |last=Yergin |first=Daniel |date=September 3, 2009 |title=The Pennsylvania Start-up That Changed The World |url=https://www.forbes.com/2009/09/03/oil-daniel-yergin-business-energy-oil.html | work=[[Forbes]] |location= |access-date=December 23, 2017}} He has also been interviewed about energy policy and international politics on various television programs.{{cite news |last=Belvedere |first=Matthew J. |date=June 15, 2017 |title=Putin is motivated to stick with OPEC's output cuts purely by self-interest, oil analyst Yergin says |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/06/15/putin-is-motivated-to-stick-with-opecs-cuts-by-self-interest-yergin.html | work=[[CNBC]] |location= |access-date=December 23, 2017}} In 2003{{cite news |last=Pearson |first=Hampton |date=August 19, 2003 |title=Washington focuses on energy bill |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/3072828/ns/business-cnbc_tv/ | work=[[CNBC]] TV |location= |access-date=December 23, 2017}} he became [[CNBC]]’s global energy expert,{{Citation |title=Daniel Yergin |publisher=[[Library of Congress]] and [[National Book Festival]] |publication-place= |page= |url=https://www.loc.gov/bookfest/author/daniel_yergin |accessdate=December 23, 2017 }} and in September 2011 he appeared on ''[[The Colbert Report]]'' to discuss wind and solar power.{{Citation |last= |first= |date=September 21, 2011 |title=September 21, 2011 - Daniel Yergin |publisher=''[[The Colbert Report]]'' |publication-place= |page= |url=http://www.cc.com/episodes/qhr36v/the-colbert-report-september-21--2011---daniel-yergin-season-7-ep-07119 |accessdate= December 23, 2017}} ===Peak oil criticisms=== Yergin criticized predictions of imminent [[peak oil]], noting in 2011 that the early 21st century is the fifth period of widespread predictions that world oil production was about to fall. The four previous times when experts commonly predicted that oil production would soon decrease were: first in the 1880s, then after each of the World Wars, and again in the 1970s. He wrote that [[Hubbert peak]] theory ignores the effects of economics and technological advances. Instead of a peak, Yergin predicts future oil production will be more of a plateau, as increasing prices moderate demand and stimulate production.Yergin, Daniel. [https://www.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424053111904060604576572552998674340 "There will be oil"], ''The Wall Street Journal'', September 17, 2011.{{cite web | url=http://video.foxbusiness.com/v/embed.js?id=1174676277001&w=466&h=263 | title=Daniel Yergin on Fox Business | work=Fox Business News | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130523015259/http://video.foxbusiness.com/v/embed.js?id=1174676277001&w=466&h=263 | archivedate=May 23, 2013 | df=mdy-all }}{{cite web|last=Gross|first=Daniel|title=U.S. incentives for renewable energy raise questions|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/27/business/worldbusiness/27iht-startup.4.5886367.html?_r=1|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=May 29, 2012}}{{cite news|last=Yergin|first=Daniel|title=The Perils, Prizes and Pitfalls of a Post-Gaddafi Era of Oil|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/1b0d3e0c-ee76-11e0-a2ed-00144feab49a.html#axzz1bLRABicT|accessdate=May 29, 2012|newspaper=[[Financial Times]]}} He also addressed peak oil in a chapter in ''The Quest'' entitled “Is the World Running Out of Oil?”’’[[The Quest: Energy, Security, and the Remaking of the Modern World]]’’ New York: Simon & Schuster, 1991. {{ISBN|0-671-50248-4}}. Reprint: Simon & Schuster, 1992, {{ISBN|0-671-79932-0}}. Yergin's skepticism toward peak oil has in turn been criticized by the theory's defenders.{{cite news |last= |first= |date= |title=Holding Daniel Yergin and CERA Accountable |url=http://www.theoildrum.com/node/3487 | work=[[The Oil Drum]] |location=Colorado, United States |access-date=December 21, 2017}}{{cite web |title=Is Yergin Correct about Oil Supply? (an Opinion the WSJ did not run) |url = http://ourfiniteworld.com/2011/09/29/is-yergin-correct-about-oil-supply-an-opinion-the-wsj-did-not-run/ |work=Our Finite World |date=September 29, 2011 |first= Gail |last=Tverberg}} For example, [[Jean Laherrère]] contended in 2011 that Yergin's predictions on energy production and prices omitted key facts, leading Yergin to draw incorrect conclusions.{{cite news|title=Peak Oil : Laherrère responds to Yergin|url=http://petrole.blog.lemonde.fr/2011/09/26/peak-oil-laherrere-responds-to-yergin/|newspaper=[[Le Monde]]}} Another industry observer criticized Yergin's statement in September 2007 that the price of crude oil was then higher than justified by fundamentals. At the time of Yergin's statement, the price of [[West Texas Intermediate]] oil was US$79 per barrel. The price peaked nine months later at US$145 per barrel before dropping dramatically to US$30 in the [[2008 financial crisis]][http://www.eia.gov/dnav/pet/hist/LeafHandler.ashx?n=PET&s=RWTC&f=D WTI Spot Price], US Energy Information Administration. Retrieved January 31, 2017.{{dead link|date=December 2017}} before rising again, and then collapsing again due to oversupply in 2014.{{cite news |last= Yergin|first=Daniel |date=May 16, 2017 |title=The Struggle Behind Oil’s Ups and Downs |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-struggle-behind-oils-ups-and-downs-1494976842 | work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |location=New York City, New York, United States |access-date=December 21, 2017}} Most recently, Yergin chaired IHS Markit’s study on “Reinventing the Wheel,” which focused on changing transportation methods, the role of electric vehicles, and the timing of peak oil demand.{{cite news |date=September 2017 |title=Reinventing the Wheel: The future of cars, oil, chemicals, and electric power |url= https://cdn.ihs.com/www/pdf/Reinventing-the-Wheel-2017.pdf | work=IHS Markit|access-date=December 23, 2017}} ==Memberships and directorships== Yergin remains vice chairman of IHS Markit. {{cite news |last= Osborne|first=James |date=March 4, 2017 |title=CERAWeek: 'Forces of change' expected to dominate conversation |url=http://www.houstonchronicle.com/business/article/At-CERAWeek-forces-of-change-expected-to-10977001.php | work=[[Houston Chronicle]] |location=Houston, Texas, United States |access-date=December 23, 2017}} He previously chaired the [[US Department of Energy]]'s Task Force on Strategic Energy Research and Development. He is a trustee of the [[Brookings Institution]], where he chairs the energy security roundtable.{{cite news|date=June 24, 2014 |title=Daniel Yergin Congressional Testimony -- Joint Economic Committee of the United States |url=http://news.ihsmarkit.com/press-release/energy-power-media/daniel-yergin-congressional-testimony-joint-economic-committee-unit?page=9 | work=IHS Markit |access-date=December 23, 2017}} He is currently a director on the [[Council on Foreign Relations]], [[United States Energy Association]], the [[U.S.-Russia Business Council]], and director emeritus of the [[New America (organization)|New America Foundation]]. He serves on the [[National Petroleum Council (US)|National Petroleum Council]], which advises the [[U.S. Secretary of Energy]]. He is on the advisory boards of the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] Energy Initiative, the [[Columbia University]] Center on Global Energy Policy, and [[Singapore]]'s International Energy Advisory Panel. Yergin was a member of the Secretary of Energy Advisory Board under Presidents [[Bill Clinton]], [[George W. Bush]], and [[Barack Obama]].{{Citation |last= |first= |year= |title=Global Perspectives with Daniel Yergin |publisher=Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas |publication-place= |page= |url=https://www.dallasfed.org/institute/events/2018/18yergin |accessdate= December 24, 2017}} In December 2016 Yergin joined a business forum composed primarily of CEOs assembled to provide strategic and policy advice on economic issues to President [[Donald J. Trump|Donald Trump]].{{cite news|last1=Bryan|first1=Bob|title=Trump is forming an economic advisory team with the CEOs of Disney, General Motors, JPMorgan, and more|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/trump-strategic-and-policy-forum-includes-dimon-iger-schwarzman-2016-12|accessdate=1 June 2017|publisher=[[Business Insider]]|date=2 Dec 2016}} The forum was disbanded in August 2017.{{cite news |last=Domm |first=Patti |date= August 16, 2017 |title='Firestorm' over Trump's latest tirade prompted top CEOs to disband advisory council |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/08/16/a-second-trump-advisory-council-is-disbanding.html | work=CNBC |location= |access-date=December 23, 2017}} == Awards == Yergin was awarded the 1997 {{cite news |last=Smith |first=Abby |date= April 14, 2014|title=Pulitzer-Prize winning author speaks about energy, global politics |url=http://www.lehighvalleylive.com/thebrownandwhitenews/index.ssf/2014/04/pulitzer-prize_winning_author.html| work=Lehigh Valley Live |location= |access-date=December 21, 2017}} United States Energy Award for "lifelong achievements in energy and the promotion of international understanding.”{{Citation |last= |first= |year= |title=Daniel H. Yergin |publisher=[[Council on Foreign Relations]] |publication-place= |page= |url=https://www.cfr.org/experts/daniel-h-yergin |accessdate=December 22, 2017 }} In 2014 the [[Prime Minister of India]] presented Yergin{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/energy-medals-yergin-idUSL2N0RV2X720141001|title=U.S. grants first medal on energy to oil historian Yergin|date=2017-10-01|work=[[Reuters]]|access-date=2017-05-11}} with a Lifetime Achievement Award, and in 2015 the [[University of Pennsylvania]] presented him with the first Carnot Prize for “distinguished contributions to energy policy.”{{Cite web|url=https://news.upenn.edu/news/penn-kleinman-center-awards-inaugural-carnot-prize-to-daniel-yergin|title=Penn’s Kleinman Center for Energy Policy Awards the Inaugural Carnot Prize to IHS Vice Chairman Daniel Yergin|website=news.upenn.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-05-11}} The [[United States Department of Energy|U.S. Department of Energy]] awarded him the first [[James R. Schlesinger|James Schlesinger]] Medal for Energy Security in 2014. ==Publishing history== ===Books as author=== *''Shattered Peace: The Origins of the Cold War and the National Security State''. New York: Houghton Mifflin, 1977. Reprints: Penguin, 1978, 1980, {{ISBN|0-395-27267-X}}; Penguin, rev. & updated, 1990, {{ISBN|0-14-012177-3}}. *''[[The Prize: The Epic Quest for Oil, Money, and Power]]''. New York: Simon & Schuster, 1991. {{ISBN|0-671-50248-4}}. Reprint: Simon & Schuster, 1992, {{ISBN|0-671-79932-0}}. *''[[The Quest: Energy, Security, and the Remaking of the Modern World]]''. [[Penguin Group|Penguin Press]], 2011. {{ISBN|978-1-59420-283-4}}.[http://www.publishersweekly.com/978-1-59420-283-4 The Quest: Energy, Security, and the Remaking of the Modern World], ''[[Publishers Weekly]]'', July 11, 2011 ===Books as co-author=== *''Energy Future: The Report of the Energy Project at the Harvard Business School''. New York: Random House, 1979. {{ISBN|0-394-50163-2}}. Reprints: Ballantine Books, {{ISBN|0-394-29349-5}}; Knopf, 3rd ed., 1982, {{ISBN|0-394-71063-0}}; Random House, new revised 3rd ed., 1990. [With Robert B. Stobaugh.] *''Global Insecurity: A Strategy for Energy and Economic Renewal''. New York: Houghton Mifflin, 1982. {{ISBN|0-395-30517-9}}. Reprint: Viking Penguin Books, 1983, {{ISBN|0-14-006752-3}}. [With [[Martin Hillenbrand]].] *''Russia 2010: And What It Means for the World''. New York: Random House, 1993. {{ISBN|0-679-42995-6}}. Reprint: Vintage, 1995, {{ISBN|0-679-75922-0}}. [With [[Thane Gustafson]].] *''[[Commanding Heights: The Battle for the World Economy|The Commanding Heights: The Battle for the World Economy]]''. Revised, retitled, and updated ed. New York: Free Press, 2002. {{ISBN|0-684-83569-X}}. (Original edition, entitled: ''The Commanding Heights: The Battle Between Government and the Marketplace That Is Remaking the Modern World'': New York: Simon & Schuster, 1998; {{ISBN|0-684-82975-4}}.) [With [[Joseph A. Stanislaw]].] ==See also== *[[List of Yale University people]] *[[List of American non-fiction environmental writers]] *[[List of economic advisors to Donald Trump]] *[[List of University of Cambridge people]] *[[Predicting the timing of peak oil]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} *[http://danielyergin.com/ Official website] *{{C-SPAN|danielyergin}} *{{IMDb name|0947593}} *{{Worldcat id|lccn-n79-129186}} {{PulitzerPrize GeneralNon-Fiction 1976–2000}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Yergin, Daniel}} [[Category:American non-fiction environmental writers]] [[Category:Pulitzer Prize for General Non-Fiction winners]] [[Category:1947 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American economics writers]] [[Category:Marshall Scholars]] [[Category:People associated with energy]] [[Category:Harvard Business School faculty]] [[Category:John F. Kennedy School of Government faculty]] [[Category:Beverly Hills High School alumni]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Cambridge]] [[Category:Yale University alumni]] [[Category:20th-century American male writers]] [[Category:21st-century American male writers]] [[Category:20th-century American historians]] [[Category:21st-century American historians]] [[Category:20th-century American non-fiction writers]] [[Category:21st-century American non-fiction writers]] [[Category:American nature writers]] [[Category:American male non-fiction writers]]

{{Infobox book | name = Emergency: This Book Will Save Your Life | image = Neil Strauss Emergency Cover.jpg | image_size = 200px | author = [[Neil Strauss]] | illustrator = [[Bernard Chang]] | cover_artist = [[Todd Gallopo]] | country = United States | language = English | subject = [[Survivalism]] | publisher = [[HarperCollins]] (US)
[[Canongate Books|Canongate]] (UK) | pub_date = March 10, 2009 (US)
April 2, 2009 (UK) | media_type = Print ([[Paperback]]) | pages = 418 p. | isbn = 0-06-089877-1 |isbn_note= (US)
{{ISBN|1-84767-527-1}} (UK) | congress = PN (US)
HV (UK) }} '''''Emergency: This Book Will Save Your Life''''' (published as '''''Emergency : One Man's Story Of A Dangerous World And How To Stay Alive In It''''' by [[Canongate Books|Canongate]]) is a 2009 book on [[survivalism|survivalist]] preparedness by [[Neil Strauss]]. In the book, the author gains citizenship of the island nation of [[St. Kitts]], visits a ranch called [[Gunsite]] to learn to shoot, and learns techniques for tracking and surviving in the wilderness. [[Comics]] are used as illustrations throughout the book, detailing survival techniques. The book culminates with author responding to the disaster site of [[2008 Chatsworth train collision]] as an emergency search and rescue team member. {{cite news| url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/books/article6204279.ece | work=The Times | location=London | title=Swine flu...recession...should we all be reading Neil Strauss to survive | first=Kate | last=Muir | date=May 2, 2009 | accessdate=May 1, 2010}} {{cite web |url=http://www2.macleans.ca/2009/03/26/macleans-interview-neil-strauss/ |title=Neil Strauss - The Interview |publisher=[[Macleans.ca]] |accessdate=March 26, 2009 |last=McKinnell |first=Julia |date=March 26, 2009 }} {{cite web|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/features/booksmags/chi-0321-strauss-survival-tipsmar21,0,2141259.story |title='Emergency: This Book Will Save Your Life' author Neil Strauss plans for the worst |work=[[Chicago Tribune]] |accessdate=March 26, 2009 |last=Esposito |first=Michael |date=March 21, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090408033021/http://www.chicagotribune.com/features/booksmags/chi-0321-strauss-survival-tipsmar21,0,2141259.story |archivedate=April 8, 2009 }} {{cite web |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2009/03/13/RV7D168DUT.DTL |title='Emergency,' by Neil Strauss |publisher=[[Sfgate.com]] |accessdate=March 26, 2009 |last=Berton |first=Justin |date=March 15, 2009 }} {{cite web |url=http://www.latimes.com/features/books/la-et-neil-strauss10-2009mar10,0,3090645.story |title=Neil Strauss is ready for any emergency |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |accessdate=March 26, 2009 |last=Carpenter |first=Susan |date=March 10, 2009 }} {{cite web |url=http://www.boston.com/ae/books/articles/2009/03/21/infiltrating_the_survivalists/ |title='Emergency' gets inside the survivalists |work=[[The Boston Globe]] |accessdate=March 26, 2009 |last=Leddy |first=Chuck |date=March 21, 2009 }} == References == {{reflist}} ==See also== * [[James Wesley Rawles]] * [[Survivalism]] [[Category:Books about survival]] [[Category:2009 books]] [[Category:HarperCollins books]] {{nonfiction-book-stub}}

[[File:Hidrocentrala Dubrava - zgrada.jpg|thumb|[[Dubrava Hydroelectric Power Plant]]]] '''Energy in Croatia''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption|energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Croatia]].
[[Croatia]] satisfies its [[electricity]] needs largely from [[hydropower|hydro]] and [[thermal power station|thermal]] power plants, and partly from the [[Krško Nuclear Power Plant|Krško nuclear power plant]], which is co-owned by Croatian and [[Slovenia|Slovenian]] state-owned power companies.
''[[Hrvatska elektroprivreda]]'' (HEP) is the national energy company charged with production, transmission and distribution of electricity.
In 2009, electricity consumption totaled 17.5 terawatt-hours, which is about 1% less than in 2008.<ref>[http://www.hep.hr/hep/publikacije/godisnje/god2009.pdf HEP 2009 annual report]</ref>
==Electricity== ===Production=== [[File:Electric energy in Croatia.png|thumb|right|325px|Energy production in Croatia]] Total installed capacity of generating objects built in Croatia amounts to 3745 MW, 2079 MW of which is hydropower's share, and 1666 MW comes from thermal power plants. There are 25 hydroelectric power plants, most of which are located on the coast (including the single [[Pumped-storage hydroelectricity|pumped storage hydroelectric plant]], RHE Velebit), and 7 thermal power stations, 3 of which also generate heat for industry and heating in cities. Also, 338 MW is available from the co-owned Krško nuclear power plant, and 210 MW from the privately owned Plomin 2 thermal power plant.<ref>http://www.hep.hr/proizvodnja/en/basicdata/default.aspx HEP Basic Production Data</ref>
In 2009, domestic production amounted to 12015 GWh, which was 67.9% of total domestic demand. Remaining 32.1% was covered through trade. Total consumption equaled 17697 GWh, a 1% decrease from 2008.<ref>http://www.hep.hr/ops/en/hees/data.aspx HEP electricity data</ref>
===Transmission=== Croatian transmission grid consists of lines on three different rated voltage levels, namely 400, 220 and 110 kV. Total length of high-voltage lines is {{convert|7315|km|2|abbr=on}}.
The grid was often the target of attacks during [[Croatian War of Independence]], resulting in frequent black-outs during the period. Since then, the grid has been repaired, and reconnected to [[synchronous grid of Continental Europe]] synchronous zones 1 and 2, making it an important transit system again.<ref>http://www.hep.hr/ops/en/hees/default.aspx HEP Croatian power system</ref>
===Distribution=== Under the 2004 Energy law, customers in Croatia are allowed to choose their preferred distributor of electricity. However, HEP Operator distribucijskog sustava or HEP-ODS (a Hrvatska elektroprivreda subsidiary) remains the largest distributor to both industry and households. Its distribution grid is {{convert|132938|km|2|abbr=on}} long, with 26 764 transformers installed, totaling 14 170 MVA of power.
In 2009 there were 2 310 811 customers, 90.8% of which were households.<ref>[http://www.hep.hr/ods/publikacije/godisnje2009.pdf HEP ODS 2009 annual report]</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Croatia|Energy}} *[[Wind power in Croatia]] *[[Industry of Croatia]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Croatia topics|state=collapsed}} {{Energy in Europe}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Energy In Croatia}} [[Category:Energy in Croatia| ]]
